comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
But how does the pilot see where he's going?

And the gunner: is he strapped in? I see no straps.
What is he standng on -- his seat?

comment.author: 7616427@N07
comment._content:
Pilot would lean to the left, or lean to the right to see around the gunner.

I can't quite tell what plane this is (looks like an early wing-warper), but most early war planes were used for observation work (troop movements &  ground photography) and were not "Fighter planes".  I suspect this was more of an observation plane then a "Fighter Plane" mostly since the extra weight of gunner, wing warping (IE- no wing rudders, the wings would be pulled by pulleys and warp) and the increased wind shield would have made this plane pretty slow and not very maneuverable.

For early biplanes they would have mounted the gun/guns on the upper wing above the prop, or in some cases, they would armour the prop and just threw it.
